questions.text: A 50-year-old male was rushed to the ER with complaints of chest pain for the past 45 minutes and was started on isosorbide mononitrate. How does this drug act?
questions.solution:
Nitrates like isosorbide mononitrate act by increasing the concentration of the second messenger cGMP.

They are used to relieve angina and cause vasodilation.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not used in angina?
questions.solution:
Sacubitril is not used in angina. Sacubitril is a neprilysin inhibitor, approved for use in the treatment of heart failure.

 

Related Pearl: Anti-anginal drugs

Anti-anginal drugs can be divided into the following categories:

  • Nitrates - dilates veins > arteries, reduces preload
  • Calcium channel blockers - blocks L-type calcium channels
    • Dihydropyridines - amlodipine, nifedipine
    • Non-dihydropyridines - verapamil, diltiazem
  • Beta-blockers - decreases heart rate, contractility and oxygen demand
  • Other drugs: 
    • Ranolazine - late Na+ channel blocker
    • Ivabradine - inhibit funny currents in SA node
    • Nicorandil - K+-ATP channel agonist
    • Trimetazidine - pFOX inhibitor
    • Fasudil - rho-kinase inhibitor

questions.text: A patient with Prinzmetal angina is administered isosorbide mononitrate and is noticed to have symptomatic relief. What is the mechanism of action of nitrate in this case?

choices.text: Increased left ventricular end diastolic volume

questions.solution:
The mechanism of action of nitrates in prinzmetal angina is endothelium-independent coronary vasodilatation.

Prinzmetal angina occurs due to vasospasm of the coronary arteries. Nitrates relax the smooth muscles of epicardial coronary arteries and relieve coronary artery spasm.

In the case of stable angina, the primary mechanism of action of nitrates is preferential dilatation of veins (by increasing cGMP). Venous dilatation leads to a decrease in the venous return to the heart (preload). This decreases the ventricular end-diastolic volume and thereby a decrease in myocardial oxygen consumption. The diastolic perfusion pressure (aortic blood pressure in diastole - left ventricular pressure in diastole) is increased.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient who suffers from prinzmetal angina requires a formulation of nitroglycerine which has the most rapid onset of action. Which of the following formulations of nitroglycerin can be administered to the patient?
questions.solution:
The sublingual route of administration has a very rapid onset of action (1-3 mins). The onset of action is more rapid when administered as a spray when compared to a tablet. 

The sublingual route is used for the termination of attacks. Oral extended-release capsule and transdermal patch are used for prophylaxis. The onset of action is approximately ≥60 min.

Topical nitroglycerine ointment can be used to provide symptomatic relief in patients with anal fissures.

questions.text: In patients with angina, nitroglycerine should not be administered by which of the following routes?
questions.solution:
Intramuscular nitroglycerin should be avoided due to severe pain in the injection area in patients with angina.

Sublingual and intravenous nitroglycerin can be used for acute effects. Oral extended-release capsules are available for prophylactic use in angina.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man suspected to have cyanide poisoning is brought to the ER. The medical officer stabilizes the patient and asks the nurse to bring an ampoule of amyl nitrite. By which of the following routes is this drug administered?
questions.solution:
Amyl nitrite is administered via the inhalational route for acute relief in angina and cyanide poisoning. 

Amyl nitrite is a highly volatile liquid available in glass ampoules. Its unpleasant odor and very short duration of action have made its use obsolete in angina.

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy was brought to the ER in an unconscious state. His coworker states he works in a factory manufacturing pesticides. Based on this, the medical officer suspects cyanide poisoning and administers sodium nitrite. Which of the following is the mechanism of action of this drug in this case?
questions.solution:
The mechanism of action of sodium nitrite as an antidote for cyanide poisoning is by the development of methemoglobinemia.

Cyanide binds to the cytochrome oxidase (complex IV) of the electron transport chain (ETC), thereby blocking it. When sodium nitrite is administered, it releases the nitrite ion. This ion binds to hemoglobin to form methemoglobin. The methemoglobin so formed, has a high affinity for the cyanide ion and binds to it, thus, detaching it from the cytochrome oxidase. This regenerates active cytochrome normalizing the function of ETC. 

The cyanide ion with methemoglobin forms cyanmethemoglobin. Sodium thiosulphate is administered for the elimination of this compound. The thiosulfate  forms thiocyanate ion with the cyanide and this is readily excreted.

questions.text: A middle-aged man came to the casualty with complaints of abdominal pain. On examination, it is noted that the pain radiates from the loin to the groin of the patient. The resident wants to administer a drug to the patient for symptomatic relief. Which drug is not effective in this condition?
questions.solution:
Abdominal pain radiating from loin to groin is suggestive of renal colic. Nitrates are not effective in renal colic. 

In renal colic, NSAIDs, and morphine are used for acute pain relief. Due to the short time of action of nitrates, their clinical efficacy as relaxants in genitourinary system is quite low.

Therapeutic Uses of nitrates are:

  • Angina pectoris
  • Acute coronary syndrome
  • Myocardial infarction
  • CHF
  • Biliary colic
  • Esophageal spasm

questions.text: A patient who is on treatment for angina, presents to you with erectile dysfunction. You decide against prescribing sildenafil because the patient is being treated with _____
questions.solution:
The patient would be on nitrates for angina and thus should not be prescribed sildenafil as sildenafil causes dangerous potentiation of nitrate action resulting in severe hypotension.

The combination of the two drugs has a synergistic action on the intracellular cGMP levels that can result in uninhibited vasodilation and a precipitous fall in blood pressure. Hence, the use of sildenafil is a contraindication when on nitrates.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male, who works in a factory that manufactures explosives, came to the OPD with a peculiar complaint. He says that he gets headaches and feels transient dizziness every Monday after his weekend off. Exposure to which compound is likely to produce his symptoms?
questions.solution:
The patient is most likely suffering from Monday disease which is associated with exposure to nitroglycerin.

Continuous exposure to high levels of nitrates can occur in the chemical industry, especially where explosives are manufactured.

When contamination of the workplace with nitrate compounds is severe, workers find that upon starting their week, they suffer headaches and transient dizziness. After a day or so back at work, tolerance develops. Over the weekend, when exposure to the chemicals is reduced, tolerance disappears, so symptoms recur each Monday.

questions.text: A 60 year old male is on verapamil for angina. Which of the following is not an adverse effect of this medication?
questions.solution:
Tachycardia is not an adverse effect of verapamil.

Verapamil has a direct negative chronotropic effect on the heart. It is more likely to cause bradycardia because of its significant cardio depressant action. Any reflex stimulation of heart due to peripheral vasodilation is effectively countered by the direct effect.

Common side effects of verapamil include headache, gingival hyperplasia, and constipation.

questions.text: Nifedipine acts by blocking  ____calcium channels.
questions.solution:
Nifedipine acts by blocking L-type calcium channels.

Verapamil, diltiazem, and dihydropyridines block L-type calcium channels by binding to alpha 1 subunit. Verapamil was the first clinically used calcium channel blocker.

Related Pearl: Types of calcium channels and their blockers

Type of Calcium Channel Blockers
L type Verapamil, diltiazem, dihydropyridines
T type Flunarizine, ethosuximide, mibefradil
N type Gabapentin, ziconotide
P/Q type Omega agatoxin IVa
R type SNX-482, Omega agatoxin IIIa

questions.text: Which among the following is a newer dihydropyridine with additional N-type calcium channel blocking activity?
questions.solution:
Cilnidipine is a novel dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker that blocks both L- and N-type calcium channels.

Blockage of N-type calcium channels results in the reduction of sympathetic activity. It provides additional anti-hypertensive action without inducing reflex tachycardia.

questions.text: Which of the following is more likely to precipitate angina?
questions.solution:
Amongst the given calcium channel blockers, nifedipine is more likely to precipitate angina.

Nifedipine is a dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker having a rapid onset and short duration of action. It results in an abrupt decrease in blood pressure resulting in reflex tachycardia. Increased contractility leads to an increase in O2 demand which may precipitate angina.

Option A: Amlodipine and extended-release preparations of nifedipine do not cause a steep fall in blood pressure and subsequent activation of sympathetic tone. Therefore, they are less likely to precipitate angina. 

Options C and D: Verapamil and diltiazem have relatively less action on peripheral vascular smooth muscles. They have a direct inhibitory effect on cardiac tissue causing negative ionotropic effect (verapamil > diltiazem).

questions.text: A patient with polycystic kidney disease came to the ER with complaints of severe headache. An NCCT brain was taken and it showed subarachnoid hemorrhage. Which of the following drugs is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Nimodipine is the most appropriate drug that can be given to this patient.

Nimodipine is indicated in cerebral vasospasm following subarachnoid hemorrhage. It has a high affinity for cerebral blood vessels and appears to reduce mortality after subarachnoid hemorrhage.

questions.text: Peripheral edema seen with the use of calcium channel blockers is primarily due to which of the following mechanisms?

choices.text: Reduced glomerular filtration rate and renal blood flow
Increased hydrostatic pressure in the capillaries of lower extremeties
Decreased oncotic pressure due to loss of plasma proteins in urine
Precapillary constriction and post capillary dilation

questions.solution:
Calcium channel blockers induced peripheral edema is most likely due to increased hydrostatic pressure in the capillaries of the lower extremities.

The increased hydrostatic pressure occurs due to precapillary dilation and reflexÂ postcapillary constriction.

questions.text: A 30-year-old athlete complained of chest pain during his practice sessions. He is diagnosed to be suffering from exertional angina and is prescribed atenolol. Which of the following changes are not caused by this drug?
questions.solution:
Atenolol is a beta-blocker which increases the coronary collateral circulation, thereby increasing the blood flow towards the ischaemic region. This provides relief in exertional angina.

Beta-blockers decrease the heart rate, contractility, and arterial blood pressure. These effects are beneficial by decreasing the myocardial O2 demand. A decrease in heart rate increases the time available for myocardial perfusion.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can be used to balance the undesirable effects of beta-blockers in angina?
questions.solution:
Beta-blockers cause an increase in end-diastolic volume and ejection time. These effects can be balanced using nitrates by preferential venous dilatation, thus reducing preload.

Beta-blockers also block the baroreceptor mediated reflex tachycardia caused by nitrates due to vasodilation.

Options A and D: Verapamil and diltiazem are not combined with beta-blockers as they can cause additive suppression of SA node and AV nodal conduction.

Option C: Ivabradine is a pacemaker I(f) "funny" current inhibitor. Its addition does not reverse the undesirable effect but only adds to the bradycardia caused by beta blockers.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is associated with coronary steal phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Coronary steal phenomenon is seen with dipyridamole.

In patients with partial obstruction of coronary vasculature, a region of ischemia develops in the myocardium. In the absence of drugs, arterioles in the ischemic areas are usually maximally dilated as a result of local compensatory mechanisms. 

When dipyridamole is administered, it acts as a nonselective arteriolar dilator. It can only dilate the vessels of the normal myocardium as the vessels of the ischemic myocardium are already maximally dilated. This diverts (steals) the blood away from the ischemic myocardium towards the normal myocardium. This is termed as coronary steal phenomenon.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about ranolazine is not true?

choices.text: It is recommended as first-line treatment for acute angina.

questions.solution:
Ranolazine is not recommended as a first-line agent for acute angina. It is approved as a second-line agent for chronic angina.

Ranolazine acts by reducing late sodium current (INa) that facilitates calcium entry via the sodium-calcium exchanger. The reduction in intracellular calcium concentration results in decreased cardiac contractility. Additionally, it also reduces cardiac fatty acid oxidation and stimulates glucose metabolism. It results in a small decrease in HBA1c, thus improving glycemic control.

It is metabolized by CYP3A4 and hence should not be used with CYP3A4 inhibitors such as macrolides, imidazole antibiotics, and HIV protease inhibitors. 

The most frequent side effects are dizziness, headache, nausea, and constipation. Hypotension is uncommon.

questions.text: Which of the following is a rho-kinase inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Fasudil is a selective RhoA /rho-kinase inhibitor.

The Rho kinases (ROCK) are a family of enzymes that inhibit vascular relaxation. Their excessive activity has been noted in coronary spasm and pulmonary hypertension. Inhibiton of these enzymes results in vascular relaxation.

Option B: Ranolazine acts by reducing late sodium current (INa). This reduces calcium entry via the sodium-calcium exchanger.

Option C: Trimetazidine is a partial fatty acid oxidation (pFOX) inhibitor. 

Option D: Nicorandil is an agonist of KATP channels

questions.text: Which of the following drugs causes activation of K+-ATP channels?
questions.solution:
Nicorandil causes activation of K+-ATP channels. This leads to the hyperpolarization of the smooth muscle cells leading to vasodilatation.

It also has nitrate like cGMP dependent action. Nicorandil dilates both arteries and veins leading to a decrease in afterload and preload of the heart.

Molsidomine, isosorbide dinitrate, and nitroglycerin are nitrates. They do not act on K-ATP channels.
